fields.Title of Review: Review of Poetry & Its Others by Ramazani
fields.Description/Abstract: In Poetry and Its Others Jahan Ramazani compares poetry to other forms of language-use, including the  law, news, prayer, and song, to show how poetry synthesizes other discourses but significantly differs from them.  Ramazani (the author of A Transnational Poetics and Poetry of Mourning and editor of the Norton Anthology of Modern and Contemporary Poetry) adapts Mikhail Bakhtin’s intertextual model of the novel to explore how poetry interacts with non-poetic discourses, drawing on their varied resources but also competing with them for longevity and depth.  For example, he draws on Auden’s definition of poetry as “memorable speech” to mark it off from the ephemerality of news reports, but he also explores how poetry by Carribean and other writers represents valuable information about the world—thereby living up to Pound’s definition of literature as “news that stays news.”  Similarly, he shows how poetry, like law, commits itself to the particulars of specific cases.  But where law derives its power from the state, poetry achieves its authority by using linguistic and figurative resources to enliven the imagination and defend human dignity.  Ramazani justifies his approach through  illuminating analyses of a diverse set of poems. Recommended.
